subject: Re: [junit] Running time consuming JUnit Tests

messageBody:
So said Jason Rogers on 12/5/2002

>Just as an idea of how long unit tests should take: the project I am
>currently on has almost 1200 unit tests that run every time we run
>AllTests (which is almost every time we run tests at all) and it takes
>around 580 seconds. Some of these are actually quick
>functional/acceptance tests which are testing the object interaction.
>So, with those few taken out (about 10 - 15), our tests take under 2
>minutes.
>
>Summary: 2 minutes for somewhere around 1185 tests.

This is excellent. Mike Bowler's open source package gsbase runs tests
at about 100/second. He has >700 tests.

If you have 1185 tests in 120 seconds, that's quite good. Imagine how
great life would be if they were an order of magnitude faster,
though... :)

This has to do with understanding the role of programmer tests as
opposed to customer tests. I have some fuzzy ideas in this direction,
but nothing to make a paper possible yet. The bottom line is
understanding the importance of blazing fast programmer tests and of
separating PTs from CTs.

If you want to get into the next gear, I suggest you run CruiseControl
in the background, running all the tests, then partition the PTs from
the CTs. Hammer on the PTs until they run at 100/second. Run AllTests
only before integration.

Of course, I understand that this is a non-trivial task, but it's worth
investigating, at a minimum.
